item.title: Day 29
item.description:
January 29, 2025 - A Day of Workshops, Cubing, and Groupwork 🛠️♟️

Class Ratings 📊

  • Physics – 4/10, another uninspiring session.
  • Signals & Systems – 4/10, same old struggle to stay engaged.
  • Digital Systems – 7/10, was the better of all as usual.

Workshop Time 🛠️

  • Changed into workshop clothes after lunch and headed for some hands-on action.
  • We were split into groups of three and tasked with replicating moulds using tools like cope, drag, runner, riddle, and trowel for metal casting.
  • The task was a blast! We divided and conquered, parallelizing our efforts to work efficiently as a team.

Cubing Practice: New Moves & Timing 🔥🧩

  • Spent the evening fine-tuning my cubing skills.
  • Worked on improving my timing, learned new permutations, and explored advanced methods. Progress is slow but steady—getting better with each twist.

Overall: A day full of productive workshop fun, teamwork, and some personal growth in cubing—ending on a high note of learning new techniques. 🚀

item.title: Day 27
item.description:
January 27, 2025 - Exploring Digital Logic & New Perspectives 🔬📚

Morning Start: An Unexpected Study Session ☀️

  • Math class was canceled, but I didn’t know—ended up waking up early.
  • While everyone else was asleep, I studied Digital Design until my next class.

Class Ratings 🎓

  • Digital Systems – 8/10, as solid as ever.
  • Physics – 5/10, barely passable.
  • Signals & Systems – 4/10, not engaging at all.
  • Spent my free slot before physics class at the library, getting in some extra study time.

First Digital Systems Lab ⚡🔬

  • Worked on breadboards & NAND gates using the 7600LS IC.
  • Plotted voltage input vs. output—a simple yet fascinating experiment.
  • Key realization:
    • Nature operates entirely in analog, yet digital logic allows us to compute faster and more efficiently.
    • Someone once had the vision to go against nature’s preference and create digital computation—this thought truly stuck with me.
    • Might adopt this “go against nature to innovate” philosophy in my own life someday.

Evening: Discovering Vindhya South Mess 🍽️

  • First time visiting Vindhya South Mess for snacks.
  • Vibe check:
    • Less commercial, smaller space.
    • More homely & peaceful compared to other messes.
  • Liked the change of atmosphere, might visit again.

Wrapping Up the Day 💻

  • Ended the night with deputy coordinator CTF work—daily grind continues.

A day filled with learning, realizations, and new experiences—loving the journey! 🚀

Continued working with the Raspberry Pi 4 and TurtleBot:

  • Spent a tiring morning flashing, reflashing, corrupting, and recorrupting the memory card. It felt like an endless cycle, testing my patience at every step.
  • Ran into several frustrating issues with storage integrity, but kept pushing through.

Evening: Progress Made

All the effort paid off!

  • Successfully set up teleoperation (teleop) for the TurtleBot, allowing me to manually control its movement.
  • Achieved autodock functionality, enabling it to autonomously return to its charging dock.

The sense of accomplishment was immense, and all the hard work felt worth it in the end.

item.title: Day 8
item.description:
January 8, 2025 - A Day of Exploration in ROS2

Today was a self-paced and highly productive day as I took a deep dive into the world of Robot Operating System 2 (ROS2). Without any scheduled events or workshops, I focused on expanding my robotics knowledge and experimenting hands-on with new concepts.

Building ROS2 Nodes

My primary goal was to enhance my understanding of ROS2 by creating custom publisher and subscriber nodes. I used my laptop’s webcam to verify their functionality, and the experiment was a success! The subscriber node processed real-time data from the webcam, while the publisher efficiently relayed the output. This reinforced my understanding of ROS2’s core architecture and messaging mechanisms.
